events.title: Micrometer support
events.body:
Hi,

I would to monitor SQL-Queries on a standalone Java application. 

From my understanding `datasource-proxy` has the ability to hook into the query execution lifecycle.

Is there support planned to support micrometer metrics or do you have any other idea on how to monitor SQL-Queries?

Thanks in advance!
events.comment:
Yes, the micrometer support is provided by this new library [datasource-micrometer](https://github.com/jdbc-observations/datasource-micrometer/).
This uses the new Micrometer Tracing API added to the Micrometer `1.10.0` with this datasource-proxy library. It automatically creates Timer, LongTaskTimer, and Counter for metrics by default.

If your application uses Spring Boot 3, then you can use the `datasource-micrometer-spring-boot` starter(auto-configuration) module.
If not, you can setup your `DataSource` with the [datasource-micrometer](https://github.com/jdbc-observations/datasource-micrometer/) with [this manual configuration](https://jdbc-observations.github.io/datasource-micrometer/docs/current/docs/html/#how-to-instrument-datasource).

events.title: Always create an observation for ResultSet
events.body:
When a query result is empty, currently no result-set observation is created.
This is because the current logic creates an observation only when `ResultSet#next()` returns `true`. (empty result-set returns `false` on `next()`)

Instead of this behavior, it should always create an observation for `ResultSet`(when the `fetch` type is included for the boot property) and tag the `row-count=0` for the empty result set.

events.title: Always create observation for ResultSet
events.body:
When a query result is empty, currently no result-set observation is created.
This is because the current logic creates an observation only when `ResultSet#next()` returns `true`. (empty result-set returns `false` on `next()`)

Instead of this behavior, it should always create an observation for `ResultSet`(when the `fetch` type is included for the boot property) and tag the `row-count=0` for the empty result set.

events.title: Cannot updateMany Dynamic Content Variants
events.body:
**TL;DR**

I think that `$objectName` and `$objectNamePlural` constants in `DynamicContentItemVariants` class should be changed to `'variant'` and `'variants'` values respectively

**Issue**
If you try to use updateMany with dynamic content variants, you always get the following error from server:

`{"error":"UnknownAttributeError","description":"Invalid attribute: missing variants parameter"}`

After some debugging, I find out that this is what updateMany is sending to the server as body of the PUT request

```
{
    "items": [
        {
            "id": 23,
            "content": "Lorem Ipsum",
        }
    ]
}
```

While official documentation suggest a body formatted as follows

```
{
  "variants": [
        {
          "id": 23,
          "content": "Lorem Ipsum",
        },
    ]
}
```

As you can see (API/Traits/Resource/UpdateMany.php:35), updateMany uses class constant value as resource name, so I suppose that this is the issue

**How to Replicate**
Here my test code:

```
$client->dynamicContent()->items( $dc_id )->variants()->updateMany( [
    [
        'id' => $v_id,
        'content' => 'Lorm Ipsum'
    ]
] );
```

where `$dc_id` contains id of the Dynamic content field that I want to update and `$v_id` contains id of the specific variation that I need to change

**Possible Solution**
Changing constants values with suggested ones seems to work pretty fine for me

**Note**
I'm using version 2.2.7 of the library, but I can see that `DynamicContentItemVariants` class wasn't changed since this version

I would be happy to repeat my test with latest version if you think it could help
events.comment: Please consider merging the referred PR, we are currently working around this by issuing lots of create single variant API calls which is clearly uneffective

events.title: Upgrade to Spring Framework 5.3.24, Spring Security 5.8.0 and Spring Boot 2.7.6
events.body:
Spring Security Release Notes: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/releases/tag/5.8.0
Spring Framework Release Notes: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-framework/releases/tag/v5.3.24
Spring Boot Release Notes: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/releases/tag/v2.7.6

Ran locally: `mvn clean test` without issue

Note that the biggest change is in the versioning of **hsqldb**: from 2.3.2 to 2.7.1

This PR supersedes https://github.com/flowable/flowable-engine/pull/3530
events.comment: Thanks @dbmalkovsky. We are working on upgrading to Spring 6, Spring Boot 3 and Spring Security 6. Which would need some more changes in our code due to removals / deprecations from the Spring team. Will leave this open until we finish that other work

events.title: TaskService.getIdentityLinksForTask(taskId)
events.body:
**Describe the bug**

TaskService.getIdentityLInksForTask(taskId) is duplicating IdentityLink in results. Looks like same IdentityLink added to list twice.


**Expected behavior**

TaskService.getIdentityLInksForTask(taskId) should not duplicate IdentityLink in results.

**Code**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4571314/190918885-3d8a813f-158c-42f9-ac9e-4719126257ce.png)

**Additional context**

https://github.com/flowable/flowable-engine/blob/main/modules/flowable-task-service/src/main/java/org/flowable/task/service/impl/persistence/entity/TaskEntityImpl.java#L247-L270

Here, getCandidates method returns set, but getIdentityLinks returns map. So duplicates are removed for getCandidates method.

events.title: Historic variables API crashes after terminating process instance during multi-instance sub process or call activity
events.body: **Describe the bug** Consulting the `GET /history/historic-variable-instances` API crashes for variables "nrOfActiveInstances" and "nrOfCompletedInstances" variables when you (prematurely) stop a process instance (with the `DELETE runtime/process-instances/{processInstanceId}` API) during a multi-instance execution (eg. using the `subProcess` or `callActivity` constructs). **Expected behavior** Loading the historic variables should never crash obviously. **Code** Deploy this model ([ModelWithSubProcess.bpmn20.xml.zip](https://github.com/flowable/flowable-engine/files/10114350/ModelWithSubProcess.bpmn20.xml.zip)) to a Flowable engine, start a new process instance using the `POST runtime/process-instances` API, retrieve the process instance id from the response body and stop it again using the `DELETE runtime/process-instances/{processInstanceId}` Then go and retrieve the historic variables using the `GET history/historic-variable-instances?processInstanceId={processInstanceId}&size=500` API. This will result in an HTTP 500 server error with content: ... and log the following exception: [flowable-exception.txt](https://github.com/flowable/flowable-engine/files/10114434/flowable-exception.txt) Notice that this does work if you query for a specific variableName as long as it is not "nrOfActiveInstances" or "nrOfCompletedInstances". If you look at the database, the most noticeable thing is that the `var_type_` in `act_hi_varinst` for both variables is "bpmnParallelMultiInstanceCompleted". This is also the case when the process is still running, but at that time the API does not "crash". If you complete the process instance in a normal manner (by submitting the 3 tasks until an end event is reached), the `var_type_` for both variables is changed to "integer" and the API also continues to work as expected. **Additional context** Tested in Flowable 6.7.2 Able to reproduce in our own production and UAT environments as well as in an empty spawned [docker flowable-ui container from docker hub](https://hub.docker.com/r/flowable/flowable-ui). The same bug occurred when we use a multi-instance `callActivity` (as opposed to a mutli-instance `subProcess` in the example model above).
events.comment: Yes you are right @verheyenkoen. I've updated my comment from before. Thanks for pointing it out

events.title: Nested properties without a setter can no longer be bound in 3.0
events.body:
We are in the process of migrating to Spring Boot 3.0 and we noticed that nested properties without a setter can no longer be bound. The example in the wiki for [Nested property](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/wiki/Spring-Boot-Configuration-Binding#nested-property) no longer works.

e.g.

```java
@ConfigurationProperties(prefix = "example")
public class ExampleProperties {

    @NestedConfigurationProperty
    private final NestedProperty nested = new NestedProperty("Default", "default");

    public NestedProperty getNested() {
        return nested;
    }
}
```

```java
public class NestedProperty {

    private String name;
    private String value;

    public NestedProperty(String name, String value) {
        this.name = name;
        this.value = value;
    }

    public String getName() {
        return name;
    }

    public void setName(String name) {
        this.name = name;
    }

    public String getValue() {
        return value;
    }

    public void setValue(String value) {
        this.value = value;
    }
}
```

Test:

```java
@SpringBootTest(properties = "example.value=test")
class DemoApplicationTests {

	@Test
	void contextLoads(@Autowired ExampleProperties properties) {
		assertThat(properties.getNested().getValue()).isEqualTo("test");
	}

}
```

The test runs successfully using Spring Boot 2.7.6, but fails on 3.0.0 with:

events.title: Nested properties without a setter can no longer be bound in 3.0
events.body:
We are in the process of migrating to Spring Boot 3.0 and we noticed that nested properties without a setter can no longer be bound. The example in the wiki for [Nested property](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/wiki/Spring-Boot-Configuration-Binding#nested-property) no longer works.

e.g.

```java
@ConfigurationProperties(prefix = "example")
public class ExampleProperties {

    @NestedConfigurationProperty
    private final NestedProperty nested = new NestedProperty("Default", "default");

    public NestedProperty getNested() {
        return nested;
    }
}
```

```java
public class NestedProperty {

    private String name;
    private String value;

    public NestedProperty(String name, String value) {
        this.name = name;
        this.value = value;
    }

    public String getName() {
        return name;
    }

    public void setName(String name) {
        this.name = name;
    }

    public String getValue() {
        return value;
    }

    public void setValue(String value) {
        this.value = value;
    }
}
```

Test:

```java
@SpringBootTest(properties = "example.value=test")
class DemoApplicationTests {

	@Test
	void contextLoads(@Autowired ExampleProperties properties) {
		assertThat(properties.getNested().getValue()).isEqualTo("test");
	}

}
```

The test runs successfully using Spring Boot 2.7.6, but fails on 3.0.0 with:


events.title: Document migration for Spring Security when upgrading to Spring Boot 3.0
events.body:
Spring Security released 5.8 and 6.0 on the same day. In Spring Security 5.8 there are various deprecations (mainly from the configuration) that have been removed in 6.0. However, this is not that clear in the Spring Boot migration guide. Since there is no Spring Boot version that is using Spring Security 5.8 it means that users that are only using Spring Boot dependency management are never going to get warnings for the deprecations.

I suggest that you update the https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/wiki/Spring-Boot-3.0-Release-Notes and either link to https://docs.spring.io/spring-security/reference/5.8/migration/index.html or write what is written in https://docs.spring.io/spring-security/reference/5.8/migration/index.html#_update_to_spring_security_5_8.

I believe that this would make the upgrade to Spring Boot 3.0 easier for users that are using Spring Security
events.comment: Thanks a lot @wilkinsona. This is really appreciated.

events.title: Global help option type is wrong
events.body:
Feature added in #582 prints:
```
$ java -jar spring-shell-samples/build/libs/spring-shell-samples-3.0.0-SNAPSHOT.jar help -h
NAME
       help - Display help about available commands

SYNOPSIS
       help --command String --help String

OPTIONS
       --command or -C String
       The command to obtain help for.
       [Optional]

       --help or -h String
       help for help
       [Optional]
```

where `--help` and `-h` is just a flag, it doesn't have a type `String`.

events.title: Support shared CommandRegistration Builder
events.body: There's starting to be a need to set common things for a command registrations so it makes sense to create a supplier bean `Supplier<CommandRegistration.Builder>` for instance of a builder which could then get customized via `CommandRegistrationCustomizer` beans which takes instance of a builder.

events.title: Global help options
events.body:
Currently help is a fully dedicated command and can be called like this.

```
my-shell:>help
my-shell:>help --command "theme style resolve"
my-shell:>help theme style resolve
```

It would be convenient to have automatic way to add options which would do same:

```
my-shell:>theme style resolve -h
my-shell:>theme style resolve --help
```

For example GO's Cobra cli lib does this by injecting these options to commands and then manually short circuit if `-h` or `--help` is parsed from an options.

events.title: Warning printed after migrating to (joinfaces 5/springboot 3)
events.body:
After migrating a project to Spring Boot v3.0 / Joinfaces v5.0.0, the following warnings are printed out :

```
WARN 15516 --- [  restartedMain] ocalVariableTableParameterNameDiscoverer : Using deprecated '-debug' fallback for parameter name resolution. Compile the affected code with '-parameters' instead or avoid its introspection: org.joinfaces.autoconfigure.scopemapping.CdiScopeAnnotationsAutoConfiguration
WARN 15516 --- [  restartedMain] ocalVariableTableParameterNameDiscoverer : Using deprecated '-debug' fallback for parameter name resolution. Compile the affected code with '-parameters' instead or avoid its introspection: org.joinfaces.autoconfigure.scopemapping.FacesScopeAnnotationsAutoConfiguration
WARN 15516 --- [  restartedMain] ocalVariableTableParameterNameDiscoverer : Using deprecated '-debug' fallback for parameter name resolution. Compile the affected code with '-parameters' instead or avoid its introspection: org.joinfaces.autoconfigure.scopemapping.Jsf3ScopeAnnotationsAutoConfiguration
WARN 15516 --- [  restartedMain] ocalVariableTableParameterNameDiscoverer : Using deprecated '-debug' fallback for parameter name resolution. Compile the affected code with '-parameters' instead or avoid its introspection: org.joinfaces.autoconfigure.faces.JakartaFaces3AutoConfiguration
WARN 15516 --- [  restartedMain] ocalVariableTableParameterNameDiscoverer : Using deprecated '-debug' fallback for parameter name resolution. Compile the affected code with '-parameters' instead or avoid its introspection: org.joinfaces.autoconfigure.javaxfaces.JsfBeansAutoConfiguration$Jsf2_3AutoConfiguration
WARN 15516 --- [  restartedMain] ocalVariableTableParameterNameDiscoverer : Using deprecated '-debug' fallback for parameter name resolution. Compile the affected code with '-parameters' instead or avoid its introspection: org.joinfaces.autoconfigure.faces.FacesServletAutoConfiguration
WARN 15516 --- [  restartedMain] ocalVariableTableParameterNameDiscoverer : Using deprecated '-debug' fallback for parameter name resolution. Compile the affected code with '-parameters' instead or avoid its introspection: org.joinfaces.autoconfigure.primefaces.PrimefacesFileUploadServletContextAutoConfiguration
WARN 15516 --- [  restartedMain] ocalVariableTableParameterNameDiscoverer : Using deprecated '-debug' fallback for parameter name resolution. Compile the affected code with '-parameters' instead or avoid its introspection: org.joinfaces.autoconfigure.servlet.initparams.ServletContextInitParameterPropertiesAutoConfiguration
```

from [Spring-Framework-6 Migration Guide](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-framework/wiki/Upgrading-to-Spring-Framework-6.x) :

> **LocalVariableTableParameterNameDiscoverer** is deprecated now and logs a warning for each successful resolution attempt (it only kicks in when **StandardReflectionParameterNameDiscoverer** has not found names). Compile your Java sources with the common Java 8+ **-parameters** flag for parameter name retention (instead of relying on the **-debug** compiler flag) in order to avoid that warning, or report it to the maintainers of the affected code. With the Kotlin compiler, we recommend the **-java-parameters** flag for completeness.

I have added **-parameters** flag to **maven-compiler-plugin** but no luck !
```
<compilerArgs>
    <arg>-parameters</arg>
</compilerArgs>
```
events.comment: This should be fixed in 10368f44a040be5fae394cead726366771c2de00

events.title: Circular references problem when using RestTemplateBuilder on custom WebMvcConfigurer
events.body:
Hi,

We encounter a circular references problem when using `spring-boot-starter-data-rest` with Azure AAD Starter `spring-cloud-azure-starter-active-directory`, refer https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-java/issues/31497.

The problem will be resolved when change `spring-boot-starter-data-rest` to `spring-boot-starter-web`.

I investigate it and find that the `mvcConversionService` bean used in  [RepositoryRestMvcConfiguration](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-data-rest/blob/main/spring-data-rest-webmvc/src/main/java/org/springframework/data/rest/webmvc/config/RepositoryRestMvcConfiguration.java#L876) cause the problem, more details could see https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-java/issues/31497#issuecomment-1288458597.

The azure issue mentioned before describe how to reproduce the problem. If you think Azure AAD Starter is complex, I created a [easily sample](https://github.com/fangjian0423/spring-data-rest-circular-reference-problem) to reproduce it.

Are there any workarounds for this or any plans to fix it? thanks!
events.comment:
There are any updates on this issue?

Thank you very much!

events.title: [BUG] Circular references about restTemplateBuilder
events.body:
**Describe the bug**
A Spring Boot 2.7.4 application having dependencies on both spring-boot-starter-data-rest and spring-cloud-azure-starter-active-directory 4.4.0 fails to start due to circular references. Using spring-cloud-azure-starter-active-directory 4.3.0 works fine.

***Exception or Stack Trace***
```
***************************
APPLICATION FAILED TO START
***************************

Description:

The dependencies of some of the beans in the application context form a cycle:

   com.azure.spring.cloud.autoconfigure.aad.AadAuthenticationFilterAutoConfiguration
┌─────┐
|  restTemplateBuilder defined in class path resource [org/springframework/boot/autoconfigure/web/client/RestTemplateAutoConfiguration.class]
↑     ↓
|  restTemplateBuilderConfigurer defined in class path resource [org/springframework/boot/autoconfigure/web/client/RestTemplateAutoConfiguration.class]
↑     ↓
|  messageConverters defined in class path resource [org/springframework/boot/autoconfigure/http/HttpMessageConvertersAutoConfiguration.class]
↑     ↓
|  jacksonHttpMessageConverter defined in class path resource [org/springframework/data/rest/webmvc/config/RepositoryRestMvcConfiguration.class]
↑     ↓
|  linkCollector defined in class path resource [org/springframework/data/rest/webmvc/config/RepositoryRestMvcConfiguration.class]
↑     ↓
|  selfLinkProvider defined in class path resource [org/springframework/data/rest/webmvc/config/RepositoryRestMvcConfiguration.class]
↑     ↓
|  org.springframework.boot.autoconfigure.web.servlet.WebMvcAutoConfiguration$EnableWebMvcConfiguration
↑     ↓
|  org.springframework.security.config.annotation.web.configuration.OAuth2ClientConfiguration$OAuth2ClientWebMvcSecurityConfiguration
↑     ↓
|  com.azure.spring.cloud.autoconfigure.aad.configuration.AadOAuth2ClientConfiguration
└─────┘


Action:

Relying upon circular references is discouraged and they are prohibited by default. Update your application to remove the dependency cycle between beans. As a last resort, it may be possible to break the cycle automatically by setting spring.main.allow-circular-references to true.
```

**To Reproduce**
Create a new Spring Boot project at https://start.spring.io/ and select the following dependencies:
* Rest Repositories
* Azure Active Directory
* Spring Security
* OAuth2 Client 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8725098/195890647-07d830d6-42c6-4251-8ad9-f2c1a18e501b.png)

Then enable AAD in the application.yaml file:
```
spring:
  cloud:
    azure:
      active-directory:
        enabled: true
        credential:
          client-id: whatever
          client-secret: whatever
        profile:
          tenant-id: whatever
        user-group:
          allowed-group-names: whatever
```

***Code Snippet***
N/A

**Expected behavior**
The Spring Boot application starts (and immediately terminates because it's not a web application) without error.

**Screenshots**
N/A

**Setup (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Windows
 - IDE: IntelliJ
 - Library/Libraries:
 * org.springframework.boot:spring-boot-starter-data-rest:2.7.4
 * org.springframework.boot:spring-boot-starter-oauth2-client:2.7.4
 * org.springframework.boot:spring-boot-starter-security:2.7.4
 * com.azure.spring:spring-cloud-azure-starter-active-directory:4.4.0
 - Java version: 11 
 - App Server/Environment: N/A
 - Frameworks: Spring Boot 2.7.4 

**Additional context**
This could be related to https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-java/pull/31048
Downgrading to com.azure.spring:spring-cloud-azure-starter-active-directory:4.3.0 solves the problem.
Removing the org.springframework.boot:spring-boot-starter-data-rest dependency also "solves" the problem.

**Information Checklist**
Kindly make sure that you have added all the following information above and checkoff the required fields otherwise we will treat the issuer as an incomplete report
- [x] Bug Description Added
- [x] Repro Steps Added
- [x] Setup information Added
events.comment:
There are any updates on this issue?

Thank you very much!

events.title: Component: VirtualScroller
events.body:
### Describe the bug

VirtualScroller triggers onLazyLoad event even though there is no scroll event.

You can view the console on this [demo](https://stackblitz.com/edit/primeng-virtualscroller-demo-cqpv7h)

Open up the console and you will see the event being logged constantly.

### Environment

Simple angular project with latest version of angular and primeng

### Reproducer

https://stackblitz.com/edit/primeng-virtualscroller-demo-cqpv7h

### Angular version

14.2.3

### PrimeNG version

14.1.2

### Build / Runtime

Angular CLI App

### Language

TypeScript

### Node version (for AoT issues node --version)

16.14.2

### Browser(s)

_No response_

### Steps to reproduce the behavior

1. Open up the console
2. You'll see the event being logged constantly.

### Expected behavior

I would expect the lazyLoad event to trigger when there is a scroll event.
events.comment: Thank you so much @yelhouti ! I appreciate the work of your guys!

events.title: Problem with jakarta JMS and brave for spring boot 3.0 BOM
events.body:
Sorry if its wrong project, please point me there I can report it.

According to 
https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/docs/3.0.0/reference/html/dependency-versions.html#appendix.dependency-versions.coordinates
brave version is 5.14.1, but for JMS it uses `javax` package. It is incompatible with SpringBoot 3.0 expectation.
https://github.com/openzipkin/brave/blob/5.14.1/instrumentation/jms/src/main/java/brave/jms/JmsTracing.java#L34
events.comment: This has nothing to do with Boot. You should create an issue in Brave. We can instrument JMS in Spring without using JmsTracing.

events.title: [BUG] Loosing getter spanKind
events.body:
By creating anonymous lambda we effectively lost `RemoteGetter` type for the getter.
It means there is no way to distinct span kind (brave.propagation.Propagation.RemoteGetter#spanKind) inside custom Propagator

io.micrometer.tracing.handler.PropagatingReceiverTracingObservationHandler#onStart
```java
        Span.Builder extractedSpan = this.propagator.extract(context.getCarrier(),
                (carrier, key) -> context.getGetter().get(carrier, key));
```
events.comment: I understand that you have a custom instrumentation? Or do you want to have this info for any existing instrumentation?

events.title: Traces missing/changed with WebFluxSleuthOperators.withSpanInScope in cloud-gateway
events.body:
**Describe the bug**

**Version details**
spring-cloud-gateway: 3.1.4
spring-cloud-sleuth: 3.1.4

**Issue**
Recently we identified an issue in cloud-gateway where we found traces and spans are missing in log at multiple places. After investigation we found its due to `spring.sleuth.reactor.instrumentation-type` is explicitly set to `manual` for cloud-gateway and this mode suggest to handle tracingContext manually by using `WebFluxSleuthOperators`, as given in this [document](https://docs.spring.io/spring-cloud-sleuth/docs/current/reference/htmlsingle/spring-cloud-sleuth.html#sleuth-reactor-integration) and [issue](https://github.com/spring-cloud/spring-cloud-sleuth/issues/1710)

This issue is not appearing with other spring boot applications because  `spring.sleuth.reactor.instrumentation-type` is set to its default value `DECORATE_ON_EACH`, which guarantee to wraps every Reactor operator in a trace representation.

We changed our code as per suggested by [document](https://docs.spring.io/spring-cloud-sleuth/docs/current/reference/htmlsingle/spring-cloud-sleuth.html#sleuth-reactor-integration) and wrap all our loggers within `WebFluxSleuthOperators.withSpanInScope`, as given below.

```
WebFluxSleuthOperators.withSpanInScope(tracing, currentTraceContext, exchange) {
                                    logger.debug("hello world ...")
                                }
```
and we found very less occurrence of missing traces and spans in logs :)

But after deep analysis of log we found, traceId and spaneId are different at some places (for the single route), where we calling some external api (through RetrofitClient) from cloud-gateway, and I believe its due missing tracingContext at the time of external call and due to this new traceId and spanId get generated. This behavior is misleading for someone who using tools like kibana to search log based on traceId, additionally in some of the cases traceId and spanId are still missing for the libraries by spring-cloud-gateway

As we used `WebFluxSleuthOperators` in our application, but we didn't have any control over external libraries like RetrofitClient, so how we need to handle such scenario.




**Sample**
Below screenshot where we are getting different traceId and spanId for single route call.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9671341/204739643-68beafef-3102-4a08-88a5-fc46e9b6af9e.png)

Below screenshot where we are not getting any traceId and spanId 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9671341/204744326-c6945e2f-a4f3-4f24-a497-a613b1370599.png)


Just want to add that by changing `spring.sleuth.reactor.instrumentation-type` to `DECORATE_ON_EACH` everything works as expected.
events.comment: Please try turning on the on queue wrapping and try again

events.title: MissingWebServerFactoryBeanException for Spring Boot WebFlux 3.0.0 + Spring Cloud Contract 4.0.0-RC3 + SpringBootTest.WebEnvironment.RANDOM_PORT
events.body:
Originally raised in https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/issues/33456 by @davidmelia

---

Hi,

If you create a Spring Boot 3.0.0 WebFlux Starter project and add
```

        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.springframework.cloud</groupId>
            <artifactId>spring-cloud-contract-wiremock</artifactId>
        </dependency>
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.springframework.cloud</groupId>
            <artifactId>spring-cloud-starter-contract-verifier</artifactId>
        </dependency>	
...
	<dependencyManagement>
		<dependencies>	          
			<dependency>
				<groupId>org.springframework.cloud</groupId>
				<artifactId>spring-cloud-dependencies</artifactId>
				<version>2022.0.0-RC3</version>
				<type>pom</type>
				<scope>import</scope>
			</dependency>	
		</dependencies>
	</dependencyManagement>	
```
then the XXXApplicationTests which have been auto created work fine unless you add webEnvironment = SpringBootTest.WebEnvironment.RANDOM_PORT e.g.

```
@ExtendWith({SpringExtension.class})
@SpringBootTest(classes = MyApplication.class, webEnvironment = SpringBootTest.WebEnvironment.RANDOM_PORT)
class ApplicationTests {

	@Test
	void contextLoads() {
	}

}
```
The above results in a _org.springframework.boot.web.context.MissingWebServerFactoryBeanException_ which is a change in behaviour to Spring Boot 2.7.x

There are a few ways around this:

1. Use SpringBootTest.WebEnvironment.MOCK or SpringBootTest.WebEnvironment.NONE
2. Add spring.main.web-application-type=REACTIVE
3. Remove Spring Cloud Contract dependencies
4. Do not upgrade to Spring Boot 3

Thanks

events.title: LOG4J2-3628 Replace maven-changes-plugin with a custom changelog implementation.
events.body:
### What is what?
* `changelog` – where changelog _sources_ are stored
* `changelog/.unreleased` – changelog sources for the next release
* `changelog/<releaseDate>-<releaseVersion>` – changelog sources for the past released versions
* `changelog/<releaseDate>-<releaseVersion>/.release.xml` – the meta information about the release (e.g., release version and date)
* `changelog/<releaseDate>-<releaseVersion>/.intro.adoc` – the introductory content used by the generator (manually copied from past announcement emails)
* `changelog/*/[<issueId>_]<shortSummary>.xml` – changelog entry associated with a change (manually populated from existing `changes.xml`)
* `src/site/asciidoc/changelog/<releaseVersion>.adoc` – generated via `log4j-internal-util`
* `src/site/asciidoc/changelog/index.adoc` – generated via `log4j-internal-util`
* `log4j-internal-util` – changelog importer (from `changes.xml`), AsciiDoc exporter, changelog releaser

### How shall a reviewer start?
* Proof-read `changelog/README.md`
* Quickly skim through `changelog/*/*.{xml,adoc}` files, since they are either generated or copied

### What is next?
1. Clone this to `master`
1. Clean duplicate `changes.xml` entries there
1. Remove changelog importer in `log4j-internal-util` from both `release-2.x` and `master` branches since it is not needed anymore
events.comment:
> I see your point. If these changelog utilities would be used by other projects besides Log4j, it would even make more sense to move it to a dedicated repository. Though, as of now, given we haven't even used it for once yet, don't you agree that it is a bit overkill to move these utilities to a separate (rusted?) repository, make a release there, so that we can use it in Log4j... just because they should be invoked from the parent project rather than a module?
No, I don't agree. If we intend to use it from a different repo we need to do that. As I said, the plugin should be referenced in the parent pom. We can't do that if the code is in a sub-module.
> You are making a release (e.g., 2.20.0), not a release candidate. The entire .unreleased-2.x.x will be converted to 20??????-2.20.0, just like your 2.20.0-SNAPSHOT artifacts have been converted to 2.2.20 and there is no turning back.
All releases are release candidates. They only become a release when the vote passes and the release tag is created.  It is not uncommon to add a new Jira to a subsequent release candidate and we cannot be precluded from doing it.
>| I didn't see an index.adoc generated anywhere.
>It works for me:
You are showing it generating .intro.adoc, not index.adoc as the README says. I see no file generated that contains all the changelog entries, which is what I thought the main point of this was.

events.comment:
I don't understand the latest changes. When running it I see
```
moving `/Users/rgoers/projects/apache/logging/log4j/release-2.x/src/changelog/.unreleased-2.x.x` to `/Users/rgoers/projects/apache/logging/log4j/release-2.x/src/changelog/20221128-2.19.1-SNAPSHOT`
writing release information to `/Users/rgoers/projects/apache/logging/log4j/release-2.x/src/changelog/20221128-2.19.1-SNAPSHOT/.release.xml`
created intro file at `/Users/rgoers/projects/apache/logging/log4j/release-2.x/src/changelog/20221128-2.19.1-SNAPSHOT/.intro.adoc
```

1. Why is it moving stuff from the unreleased directory. Won't that cause it to be lost on a subsequent invocation?
2. Why does the target have a date if everything is moved? Why wouldn't it just be 2.19.1-SNAPSHOT? 
3. Isn't there is a risk that these SNAPSHOT directories will actually be committed? 
4. I didn't see an index.adoc generated anywhere.

To be honest, I am still not comfortable with this. 
1. Why is it necessary to move files?  I would think renaming the .unreleased directory to the release number would be sufficient. This should happen as part of release:prepare.
2. Generated files are not normally added to the source but are generated under the target directory. If the tool performs step 1 and then generates a changes.adoc file with changes for all releases similar to what the maven changes plugin does then I would hope the changes.adoc file could be generated to the target directory and included by asciidoc from there.

events.title: [LOG4J2-3638] Provide a Maven plugin to inline location information
events.body:
This PR provides a simple Maven plugin with a `generate-location` goal, which process the compiled classes to add static location information.

The code is split into two modules: `log4j-instrument`, which contains the bytecode manipulation features and `log4j-maven-plugin` with the Maven plugin itself. It's less than 10 classes in total, so maybe the split is overkill.

Supported methods:
* all `Logger` methods are supported (and tested) except `catching`, `printf`, `throwing`, `traceEntry` and `traceExit`, which don't have a corresponding `LogBuilder` method,
* methods with a `(MessageSupplier)` and `(Supplier<?>)` signature are supported, but they are rewritten as `log(Supplier<Message>)` and `log(String, Supplier<?>...)` respectively due to the lack of corresponding `LogBuilder` methods. This introduces a small performance penalty and garbage, especially if the log statement is disabled.

The Maven plugin works for me (you can test with the project in `log4j-maven-plugin/src/it/location`), but it requires more testing (and unit tests) to be ready for inclusion.

All comments (naming conventions, implementation details) are welcome.
events.comment:
@ppkarwasz Would it be possible to also generate a text version of the .java file that matches the modified class file that could be used for debugging? I am guessing that a) that would be a lot of work and b) if we did that they we might as well redirect the compiler plugin to use them instead of generating a class file. 

My only concern here will be how it impacts debugging of classes.

events.comment: Sure. But that won't do any good without a release and we just created a release a few weeks ago. We also will need to create a Jira issue to track dependency changes made during the next release.

events.title: FLUME-3415 - Provide Docker image for Flume
events.body: Draft docker build and integration tests.
events.comment:
I certainly don't have an issue against providing a Docker image. I just am unclear as to how it will be useful, but I suppose if it is just used as a starting point it could work out. But the approach you mention sounds much better in the long run. I just don't want to have to support that a) I won't have any use for, and b) we will have to keep compatibility with even though we want to do something much better.

To be clear, I use the FileChannel, which pretty much requires fast disk (i.e. SSDs or equivalent) to perform well. It also requires a dedicated "disk" so that data isn't lost on restart. This doesn't really work well with Docker/Kubernetes so we don't use it for Flume.

events.title: FLUME-3415 - Provide Docker image for Flume
events.body: Draft docker build and integration tests.
events.comment:
Now that I look at this again I don't think I really understand how it helps. 

1. It packages all the artifacts whether they are required or not.
2. Unless I am mistaken, it is getting the distribution tar and using the configuration located within that. I fail to see how useful that will be as I would expect most users would have a custom configuration.

To be honest, I added Spring Boot support to simplify a LOT of this. Spring Boot packages up just the dependencies you need, uses the standard application.yml to configure Flume, and allows all the wiring of Sinks, Sources, and Channels to be performed in standard Spring Java config source files. Once packaged with the Spring Boot Maven plugin startup consists of either

1. java -Dspring.profiles.active={envName} -jar my-flume.jar
2../my-flume.jar -Dspring.profiles.active={envName}

events.title: dumpclass 得到的class文件与javac编译得到的class 文件hash存在差异的原因？
events.body:
1.通过javac HelloWorld.java 得到 class 文件 HelloWorld.class，使用md5的方式得到该class文件Hash值为「A」；通过 dumpclass 的方式从进程中恢复的 HelloWorld.class 文件，使用md5的方式得到该文件Hash值为「B」。
现象：A != B ，想咨询这个问题的原因，为何恢复后程序的class文件不同？
2.如果 java 直接运行通过 dumpclass 得到的class文件，会报错 “Expected stackmap frame at this location”，类似于没有通过JVM验证，但是加上参数 -noverify 就又可以正常运行了。这个实验似乎与上面Hash值不同的现象呼应。想咨询这里面存在某种机制么，类似于JVM运行时保护？
events.comment:
可能就是 jvm 里处理了一下。

arthas用的是 ClassFileTransformer 来 dump的。可能jvm只保证了这里返回的 byte[] 和 getResource 获取的是一样的。

然后 jvm 真正把 byte[] 加载处理之后，可能据实际情况做一些变换，或者把一些无用数据清理掉都是有可能的。 hsdb dump 下来的，是这个阶段真正运行的字节码。

需要进jvm源码里看下。

events.comment:
这个确实有点奇怪，可以下个字节码查看工具，看下哪里不一样的了。 或者自己用 javap 看下具体哪里不一样。

或者试下比较新的jvm。

events.title: stack命令, 如果判断当前jdk的版本大于9时可以使用StackWalker API
events.body:
- [ ] 我已经在 [issues](https://github.com/alibaba/arthas/issues) 里搜索，没有重复的issue。

### 环境信息

* `arthas-boot.jar` 或者 `as.sh` 的版本： 3.6.6
* Arthas 版本:  3.6.6
* 操作系统版本: 20.04.1-Ubuntu
* 目标进程的JVM版本:  java 17.0.4 2022-07-19 LTS
* 执行`arthas-boot`的版本:  3.6.6


### 期望的结果

当判断jdk版本大于9时可以使用StackWalker API去获取栈程栈信息,而不是通过抛异常的方式去获取线程栈,这样效率相对较高. 参见 https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/issues/31665
events.comment:
这个改起来可能有点麻烦，目前arthas是用jdk 8编译的。

可能需要一个单独的工具类，先编译好。或者要研究下怎么支持打包 Multi-Release Jar。

events.title: perfcounter 执行出错时提示信息不完整
events.body:
- [x] 我已经在 [issues](https://github.com/alibaba/arthas/issues) 里搜索，没有重复的issue。

### 环境信息

* Arthas 版本: 3.6.6
* 操作系统版本: 5.15.0-56-generic 20.04.1-Ubuntu
* 目标进程的JVM版本: java version "17.0.4" 2022-07-19 LTS

### 重现问题的步骤

1. attach到目标进程后执行`perfcounter`

### 期望的结果

正确输出相关结果 

### 实际运行的结果

please check arthas log. if java version >=9 , try to add jvm options when start your process: --add-opens java.base/jdk.internal.perf=ALL-UNNAMED --add-exports java.base/jdk.internal.perf=ALL-UNNAMED

```
java.lang.IllegalAccessError: class com.taobao.arthas.core.command.monitor200.PerfCounterCommand (in unnamed module @0x22b84315) cannot access class sun.management.counter.perf.PerfInstrumentation (in module java.management) because module java.management does not export sun.management.counter.perf to unnamed module @0x22b84315
	at com.taobao.arthas.core.command.monitor200.PerfCounterCommand.getPerfCounters(PerfCounterCommand.java:105)
	at com.taobao.arthas.core.command.monitor200.PerfCounterCommand.process(PerfCounterCommand.java:53)
	at com.taobao.arthas.core.shell.command.impl.AnnotatedCommandImpl.process(AnnotatedCommandImpl.java:82)
	at com.taobao.arthas.core.shell.command.impl.AnnotatedCommandImpl.access$100(AnnotatedCommandImpl.java:18)
	at com.taobao.arthas.core.shell.command.impl.AnnotatedCommandImpl$ProcessHandler.handle(AnnotatedCommandImpl.java:111)
	at com.taobao.arthas.core.shell.command.impl.AnnotatedCommandImpl$ProcessHandler.handle(AnnotatedCommandImpl.java:108)
	at com.taobao.arthas.core.shell.system.impl.ProcessImpl$CommandProcessTask.run(ProcessImpl.java:385)
	at java.base/java.util.concurrent.Executors$RunnableAdapter.call(Executors.java:539)
	at java.base/java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:264)
	at java.base/java.util.concurrent.ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor$ScheduledFutureTask.run(ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor.java:304)
	at java.base/java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1136)
	at java.base/java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:635)
	at java.base/java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:833)
```

### FIX

根据异常信息查看 未导出 ` sun.management.counter.perf.PerfInstrumentation` 使用 `java --describe-module java.management` 得出以下信息
```
java.management@17.0.4
exports java.lang.management
exports javax.management
exports javax.management.loading
exports javax.management.modelmbean
exports javax.management.monitor
exports javax.management.openmbean
exports javax.management.relation
exports javax.management.remote
exports javax.management.timer
requires java.base mandated
uses sun.management.spi.PlatformMBeanProvider
uses javax.management.remote.JMXConnectorServerProvider
uses javax.management.remote.JMXConnectorProvider
provides javax.security.auth.spi.LoginModule with com.sun.jmx.remote.security.FileLoginModule
qualified exports sun.management.counter to jdk.management.agent
qualified exports sun.management.spi to jdk.management.jfr jdk.management
qualified exports sun.management to jdk.management jdk.management.agent jdk.jconsole
qualified exports sun.management.counter.perf to jdk.management.agent
qualified exports com.sun.jmx.remote.internal to jdk.management.agent java.management.rmi
qualified exports com.sun.jmx.remote.security to jdk.management.agent java.management.rmi
qualified exports com.sun.jmx.remote.util to java.management.rmi
contains com.sun.jmx.defaults
contains com.sun.jmx.interceptor
contains com.sun.jmx.mbeanserver
```

所以需要在目标进程启动之前加上`--add-opens java.management/sun.management.counter.perf=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens java.management/sun.management.counter=ALL-UNNAMED` 启动参数 但是在执行完`perfcounter`之后并未提示相关信息.
events.comment: 欢迎提交PR😀

events.title: 匹配 interface的机制会提前加载类，导致 ClassFileTransformer#transform 丢失部分类
TransformerManagerImpl 在add reClassFileTransformer 时没有设置 canRetransform true
TransformerManagerImpl 在add reClassFileTransformer 时没有设置 canRetransform true
在 addTransformer 时，不设置 canRetransform 为 true，会有一部分类不经过 ClassFileTransformer 处理
events.body:
正常来说，一个普通的 java agent，如果是以 `-javaagent:` 方式启动，注册 ClassFileTransformer 之后，后续加载的类都会经过注册的 ClassFileTransformer 处理。

但实际发现，有部分类并不会被处理。只有注册时设置`canRetransform`为true时，才会被处理。

比如这个类：`org.springframework.beans.factory.support.AbstractAutowireCapableBeanFactory` 。

```
Instrumentation#addTransformer(ClassFileTransformer transformer, boolean canRetransform);
```

记录一下现象。

events.title: @Validated not working with GraphQlController
events.comment:
We call standard bean validation to validate all the method parameters, and it does look like [that requires `@Valid`](https://beanvalidation.org/latest-draft/spec/#constraintdeclarationvalidationprocess-methodlevelconstraints-cascadedvalidation). 

Are you trying to specify validation groups? We do check for `@Validated` on the method, so you can specify groups that way still, but otherwise as it is currently you do need `@Valid` to trigger cascaded validation.

I think we could enhance our validation support to detect method parameters with `@Validated` but without `@Valid` and to apply validation on them, in addition to invoking standard bean validation for other method parameters.

events.title: GraphQlTester should use native GraphQL serialization for variables
events.body:
### Motivation

My output types in the schema are the same as my input types except the latter ones don't have `id` field. For conciseness reasons, I use the same underlying DTO with nullable id for both types. This works well in the main code flow because `id` is set to null on input while it has some value on the output.

In the tests, though, I want to use my DTOs as input variables, e.g.
```
graphQlTester
            .document(SOME_QUERY)
            .variable("var", SomeDtoWithIdField)
            .execute()
```
Now I obviously don't want the variable `var` to contain the `id` field because it's not defined in the input type corresponding to `SomeDtoWithIdField`. I was thinking about how to drop the `id` from the serialized `var` and thought that the following code surely wouldn't work because ["GraphQL does not use Jackson annotations to drive JSON serialization/deserialization"](https://docs.spring.io/spring-graphql/docs/current/reference/html/#execution-graphqlsource-runtimewiring-configurer).
```
class SomeDtoWithIdField {
    @get:JsonIgnore
    var id: Long? = null
}
```

But my colleague tried that anyway and to my surprise, it worked :-) That is, in my test case the `id` is not serialized into `var` while in the main flow the `id` is serialized to the output type. My hypothesis is that while in the normal flow spring-grqphql uses some custom serializer, `GraphQlTester` uses Jackson.

### Questions

- Is this expected behavior? Shouldn't rather `GraphQlTester` use the same serializer as the main flow?
- If both flows should indeed behave consistently, then how could I achieve my use case? Is it somehow possible to hook into the serialization process?

(This question can be read as a sort of reverse of https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-graphql/issues/521)
events.comment: I've improved that documentation note in 089c754c73ee10a218ca6aaba4a2ca8cf2d6e9bb, based on this conversation.

events.title: GraphQlTester should use native GraphQL serialization for variables
events.body:
### Motivation

My output types in the schema are the same as my input types except the latter ones don't have `id` field. For conciseness reasons, I use the same underlying DTO with nullable id for both types. This works well in the main code flow because `id` is set to null on input while it has some value on the output.

In the tests, though, I want to use my DTOs as input variables, e.g.
```
graphQlTester
            .document(SOME_QUERY)
            .variable("var", SomeDtoWithIdField)
            .execute()
```
Now I obviously don't want the variable `var` to contain the `id` field because it's not defined in the input type corresponding to `SomeDtoWithIdField`. I was thinking about how to drop the `id` from the serialized `var` and thought that the following code surely wouldn't work because ["GraphQL does not use Jackson annotations to drive JSON serialization/deserialization"](https://docs.spring.io/spring-graphql/docs/current/reference/html/#execution-graphqlsource-runtimewiring-configurer).
```
class SomeDtoWithIdField {
    @get:JsonIgnore
    var id: Long? = null
}
```

But my colleague tried that anyway and to my surprise, it worked :-) That is, in my test case the `id` is not serialized into `var` while in the main flow the `id` is serialized to the output type. My hypothesis is that while in the normal flow spring-grqphql uses some custom serializer, `GraphQlTester` uses Jackson.

### Questions

- Is this expected behavior? Shouldn't rather `GraphQlTester` use the same serializer as the main flow?
- If both flows should indeed behave consistently, then how could I achieve my use case? Is it somehow possible to hook into the serialization process?

(This question can be read as a sort of reverse of https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-graphql/issues/521)
events.comment:
Re-reading the description again, I think I'm beginning to understand.

I think your expectation is that `GraphQlTester` will compare `SomeDtoWithIdField` to  the corresponding GraphQL schema input type and prepare maps of data that contain only the fields that exist in the schema type, and therefore the id field should not be in the resulting output. 

GraphQL Java indeed does something similar, but that's on the server side and it's for responses, and it's slightly different because it's checking against the field selection set rather than directly against the schema types. In any case, it's not something that can be re-used on the client side.

It's a valid potential enhancement, assuming I've got it right, for `GraphQlClient` and `GraphQlTester` to turn variables into maps of data, by looking at the corresponding schema input and taking only what's needed, before passing that down to the transport to serialize to JSON.

### Motivation

My output types in the schema are the same as my input types except the latter ones don't have `id` field. For conciseness reasons, I use the same underlying DTO with nullable id for both types. This works well in the main code flow because `id` is set to null on input while it has some value on the output.

In the tests, though, I want to use my DTOs as input variables, e.g.
```
graphQlTester
            .document(SOME_QUERY)
            .variable("var", SomeDtoWithIdField)
            .execute()
```
Now I obviously don't want the variable `var` to contain the `id` field because it's not defined in the input type corresponding to `SomeDtoWithIdField`. I was thinking about how to drop the `id` from the serialized `var` and thought that the following code surely wouldn't work because ["GraphQL does not use Jackson annotations to drive JSON serialization/deserialization"](https://docs.spring.io/spring-graphql/docs/current/reference/html/#execution-graphqlsource-runtimewiring-configurer).
```
class SomeDtoWithIdField {
    @get:JsonIgnore
    var id: Long? = null
}
```

But my colleague tried that anyway and to my surprise, it worked :-) That is, in my test case the `id` is not serialized into `var` while in the main flow the `id` is serialized to the output type. My hypothesis is that while in the normal flow spring-grqphql uses some custom serializer, `GraphQlTester` uses Jackson.

### Questions

- Is this expected behavior? Shouldn't rather `GraphQlTester` use the same serializer as the main flow?
- If both flows should indeed behave consistently, then how could I achieve my use case? Is it somehow possible to hook into the serialization process?

(This question can be read as a sort of reverse of https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-graphql/issues/521)
events.comment:
> Is this method also used if the transport is WebTestClientTransport? 

No, that's apples and oranges.

What I talked about is GraphQL Java returning an `ExecutionResult` with a map of data and errors assembled field by field. This then written out to JSON by our server HTTP transport. What you're asking about is `WebTestClientTransport` which is on the client side, and that has nothing to do what GraphQL Java does on the server side.

events.title: ConsumesRequestCondition should cache the parsed Content-Type
events.body:
`ProducesRequestCondition` saves the parsed Accept header in a request attribute, which is then cleared after all request mapping annotations are checked. We can do the same for `ConsumesRequestCondition`, but only on the Spring MVC side since WebFlux uses `ReadOnlyHttpHeaders` which already caches the Content-Type. 

This was observed as part of investigations for #29421.

events.body:
### Motivation

My output types in the schema are the same as my input types except the latter ones don't have `id` field. For conciseness reasons, I use the same underlying DTO with nullable id for both types. This works well in the main code flow because `id` is set to null on input while it has some value on the output.

In the tests, though, I want to use my DTOs as input variables, e.g.
```

            .document(SOME_QUERY)

I was thinking about how to drop the `id` from the serialized `var` and thought that the following code surely wouldn't work because ["GraphQL does not use Jackson annotations to drive JSON serialization/deserialization"](https://docs.spring.io/spring-graphql/docs/current/reference/html/#execution-graphqlsource-runtimewiring-configurer).
```

```
    @get:JsonIgnore
    var id: Long? = null
}
```

But my colleague tried that anyway and to my surprise, it worked :-) That is, in my test case the `id` is not serialized into `var` while in the main flow the `id` is serialized to the output type. My hypothesis is that while in the normal flow spring-grqphql uses some custom serializer, `GraphQlTester` uses Jackson.

- Is this expected behavior? Shouldn't rather `GraphQlTester` use the same serializer as the main flow?
- If both flows should indeed behave consistently, then how could I achieve my use case? Is it somehow possible to hook into the serialization process?

(This question can be read as a sort of reverse of https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-graphql/issues/521)
events.comment:
No, GraphQL doesn't serialize anything to JSON. It goes field by field and assembles the output map. 

I'm not really sure what's going on from this level of detail. Something less than obvious perhaps. The only other suggestion I have is that maybe `@JsonInclude(Include.NON_NULL)` could work better for what you're describing.

events.title: Allow custom `ExecutionStrategy` to use `DataFetcherExceptionResolver` chain
events.body:
I've found a bug that occurs when using DataFetcherExceptionResolverAdapter and a custom QueryExecutionStrategy.

For some reason, if you return a failed future the exception just gets bubbled up without passing through DataFetcherExceptionResolverAdapter. 

I've got a reproducible example here: https://github.com/JamesPeters98/SpringGraphQLErrorTest/

There is a Query and Mutation example. The mutation gets resolved correctly:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2249693/205050023-3e455a4a-302a-473c-a11b-50a7225f5672.png)

But not the query:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2249693/205050150-f641f6eb-673c-4940-8796-f2f3e5440ce1.png)

If you remove the custom QueryExecutionStrategy the exception gets resolved
events.comment:
I've added the factory method. 

Note that the created handler does not have any state, other than the list of resolvers, so in that sense it just encapsulates the logic to invoke each in turn. It's not exposed publicly so it has no other configuration properties. In that sense it should be no issue if there are two or even more instance of it. 

Also we already detect individual resolvers as beans, so it didn't seem ideal to make the handler a bean as well. It should work fine like, but if necessary we'll reconsider.

events.title: Relax generic type checks when `@Argument` binding to a map with an undeclared value type
events.body:
Currently we reject `@Argument Map<String, ?>` but that's arguably too strict. We could treat it the same way as `Map<String, Object>`, i.e. as intending to access the raw value. It's the best we can do from the given inputs, and no need to require declaring the value type as `Object`.

Originally discussed under #548.

events.body:
### Motivation

My output types in the schema are the same as my input types except the latter ones don't have `id` field. For conciseness reasons, I use the same underlying DTO with nullable id for both types. This works well in the main code flow because `id` is set to null on input while it has some value on the output.

In the tests, though, I want to use my DTOs as input variables, e.g.
```

            .document(SOME_QUERY)
            .variable("var", SomeDtoWithIdField)
            .execute()
```
Now I obviously don't want the variable `var` to contain the `id` field because it's not defined in the input type corresponding to `SomeDtoWithIdField`. I was thinking about how to drop the `id` from the serialized `var` and thought that the following code surely wouldn't work because ["GraphQL does not use Jackson annotations to drive JSON serialization/deserialization"](https://docs.spring.io/spring-graphql/docs/current/reference/html/#execution-graphqlsource-runtimewiring-configurer).
```

    @get:JsonIgnore
    var id: Long? = null
}
```

But my colleague tried that anyway and to my surprise, it worked :-) That is, in my test case the `id` is not serialized into `var` while in the main flow the `id` is serialized to the output type. My hypothesis is that while in the normal flow spring-grqphql uses some custom serializer, `GraphQlTester` uses Jackson.

### Questions

- Is this expected behavior? Shouldn't rather `GraphQlTester` use the same serializer as the main flow?
- If both flows should indeed behave consistently, then how could I achieve my use case? Is it somehow possible to hook into the serialization process?

(This question can be read as a sort of reverse of https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-graphql/issues/521)
events.comment: Not sure what you mean by normal flow because serialization happens on the client side and it depends on which client is used. `GraphQlTester` is a client, and it delegates to `GraphQlTransport`, just like `GraphQlClient` does, and it passes a `GraphQlRequest` to it with maps of data. If the transport is `WebTestClientTransport` then will be serialized to JSON via Jackson. This is all expected.

events.title: Accessing Principal from custom DataFetcher implementation
events.body:
I have a GraphQL API using the GraphQL Java library that I want to move slowly to spring-graphql.

As the first step, I put my _schema.graphqls_ definition in _resources/graphql_.

Then, I created a GraphQL configuration as follows:

```java
@Configuration
public class GraphQlConfig {

    @Bean
    public RuntimeWiringConfigurer runtimeWiringConfigurer(
            final ProjectEmailSubscriptionService emailSubscriptionService,
            final FirebaseService firebaseService,
            final ProjectService projectService,
            final PublicationService publicationService) {

        return wiringBuilder -> wiringBuilder
                .scalar(ExtendedScalars.DateTime)
                .scalar(ExtendedScalars.newAliasedScalar("URL")
                        .aliasedScalar(ExtendedScalars.Url)
                        .build())
                .type(newTypeWiring("Mutation")
                        .dataFetcher("createEmailSubscription",
                                new CreateEmailSubscriptionDataFetcher(emailSubscriptionService))
                        .dataFetcher("createPost", new CreatePostDataFetcher(publicationService))
                        .dataFetcher("deleteEmailSubscription",
                                new DeleteEmailSubscriptionDataFetcher(emailSubscriptionService))
                        .dataFetcher("deletePost", new DeletePostDataFetcher(publicationService))
                        .dataFetcher("updateEmailSubscription",
                                new UpdateEmailSubscriptionDataFetcher(emailSubscriptionService))
                        .dataFetcher("updatePost", new UpdatePostDataFetcher(publicationService)))
                .type(newTypeWiring("Organization")
                        .dataFetcher("projects", new OrganizationProjectsDataFetcher(firebaseService)))
                .type(newTypeWiring("Project")
                        .dataFetcher("emailSubscriptions", new EmailSubscriptionsDataFetcher(emailSubscriptionService))
                        .dataFetcher("posts", new ProjectPublicationsDataFetcher(publicationService)))
                .type(newTypeWiring("Query")
                        .dataFetcher("emailSubscription", new EmailSubscriptionDataFetcher(emailSubscriptionService))
                        .dataFetcher("organization", new OrganizationDataFetcher())
                        .dataFetcher("post", new PublicationDataFetcher(publicationService))
                        .dataFetcher("project", new ProjectDataFetcher(projectService)))
                .build();
    }
}
```

For now, I would like to use existing GraphQL Java data fetchers, without relying on spring-specific @QueryMappping, @SchemaMapping, and @MutationMapping annotations.

Running the spring-graphql app like this works great.

My issue is when I add authentication. I have a web security configuration that defines a filter chain for the graphql endpoint as follows:

```java
@Bean
public SecurityWebFilterChain filterChain(final ServerHttpSecurity http) {
    return build.(...).pathMatchers("/graphql").hasAuthority("API").build();
}
```

An AuthenticationManager and AuthenticationContext is defined for _API_ authority. The problem I have is that I don't know how to access a Spring security Principal object from a GraphQL java data fetcher class registered with spring-graphql:

```java
CompletableFuture<...> get(DataFetchingEnvironment environment) throws Exception {
   // how to retrieve a Principal from environment?
}
```

Debugging the app, I see the GraphQL context from the environment variable contains Spring data but the security context looks null:

![Screenshot from 2022-12-05 03-10-41](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/128898/205534150-c351b344-2631-4b7b-b1a2-eb50f1d0471d.png)

Does what I am trying to do is not possible?

```java
                        .dataFetcher("updateEmailSubscription",

                        .dataFetcher("updatePost", new UpdatePostDataFetcher(publicationService)))
                .type(newTypeWiring("Organization")
                        .dataFetcher("projects", new OrganizationProjectsDataFetcher(firebaseService)))
                .type(newTypeWiring("Project")
                        .dataFetcher("emailSubscriptions", new EmailSubscriptionsDataFetcher(emailSubscriptionService))
                        .dataFetcher("posts", new ProjectPublicationsDataFetcher(publicationService)))
                .type(newTypeWiring("Query")
                        .dataFetcher("emailSubscription", new EmailSubscriptionDataFetcher(emailSubscriptionService))

                        .dataFetcher("post", new PublicationDataFetcher(publicationService))
                        .dataFetcher("project", new ProjectDataFetcher(projectService)))
                .build();
    }

```

For now, I would like to use existing GraphQL Java data fetchers, without relying on spring-specific @QueryMappping, @SchemaMapping, and @MutationMapping annotations.

Running the spring-graphql app like this works great.

My issue is when I add authentication. I have a web security configuration that defines a filter chain for the graphql endpoint as follows:

```java
@Bean
public SecurityWebFilterChain filterChain(final ServerHttpSecurity http) {
    return build.(...).pathMatchers("/graphql").hasAuthority("API").build();
}
```

An AuthenticationManager and AuthenticationContext is defined for _API_ authority. The problem I have is that I don't know how to access a Spring security Principal object from a GraphQL java data fetcher class registered with spring-graphql:

```java
CompletableFuture<...> get(DataFetchingEnvironment environment) throws Exception {
   // how to retrieve a Principal from environment?
}
```

Debugging the app, I see the GraphQL context from the environment variable contains Spring data but the security context looks null:

![Screenshot from 2022-12-05 03-10-41](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/128898/205534150-c351b344-2631-4b7b-b1a2-eb50f1d0471d.png)

Does what I am trying to do is not possible?
events.comment:
For Spring MVC, it should be propagated via ThreadLocal, and we generally wrap `DataFetcher`s to ensure context propagation so you can try `SecurityContextHolder.getContext().getAuthentication()`. You can look at `PrincipalMethodArgumentResolver` and `AuthenticationPrincipalArgumentResolver` which to the same for controller methods.

Closing for now but  feel free to comment.

events.title: io.micrometer.context.ThreadLocalAccessor - Breaking Change - Propagates an old thread local value and subset of ThreadLocals
events.body:
Hello there,

Thanks a lot everyone for all the effort creating this library. It is great.

Although, I have found some issues

The context-propagation changes in 1.1.0, seems to have introduced a breaking change in functionality
org.springframework.graphql.execution.ThreadLocalAccessor -> io.micrometer.context.ThreadLocalAccessor

Previously when switching to another next thread, `org.springframework.graphql.execution.ThreadLocalAccessor` propagated all thread-locals that were set at that point time. For example, any thread-locals that were set/updated inside an `WebGraphQlInterceptor`, or `@QueryMapping` (servlet NIO threads) would be propagated to a `@BatchMapping` executor thread.

Now when switching to the another thread, `io.micrometer.context.ThreadLocalAccessor,` does not include the most recent value that was set into the thread-local value inside a `WebGraphQlInterceptor` or @QueryResolver. It propagated the old thread local value/s set before the interceptors/@*Mapping execute. New thread locals set inside the interceptors and mappings are not propagated at all. 

Is this because the snapshot is taken before the [execution chain executes the interceptors](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-graphql/blob/main/spring-graphql/src/main/java/org/springframework/graphql/server/DefaultWebGraphQlHandlerBuilder.java#L90)?


The issue can be reproduced here. The thread-local value set in the `MdcFilter` will be propagated. Updated/overriden/new thread-local values inside the interceptors/*mappings will not be propagated to the executor.

Please let me know if I can help further or provide more information

Thanks

PR: https://github.com/philip-jvm/learn-spring-graphql/pull/1/files
Repository: https://github.com/philip-jvm/learn-spring-graphql
events.comment: Although individual controller methods may be Reactor based or synchronous, at the level of GraphQL Java execution, it's the `AsyncExecutionStrategy` that's responsible for orchestrating all those calls, and so `GraphQLContext` is the only way to propagate context across `DataFetcher`s.

In addition we'll also create a getting started guide and a more advanced external sample.

events.title: VISA BASE I ISO8583 header values
events.body:
Hello! I'm trying to decode an ISO8583 message using a VTS (VISA test simulator) and the iso8583 package from this module.

The format of a BASE I message is:
[**header**][mti][bitmap(s)][data-elements]. 

This **header** length and type may vary. It contains fixed-length fields, plus a bitmap in the 13th header field that specifies the number of fields present after that bitmap.

Below there is example of a standard header (without the extra bitmap), extracted from the simulator:

```go
// message is the string in hex as received in the tcp channel connected to the simulator.
message := "1601020029000000000000000000000000000000000001004000000000000000104761340000000019"

// decoded is the JSON representation of message, parsed manually.
decoded := `{
    "H1":  "22",
    "H2":  "01",
    "H3":  "02",
    "H4":  "0029",
    "H5":  "000000",
    "H6":  "000000",
    "H7":  "00",
    "H8":  "0000",
    "H9":  "000000",
    "H10": "00",
    "H11": "000000",
    "H12": "00",
    "mti": "0100",
    "2":   "4761340000000019"
}
```

AFAIK, Moov, as a payment processor, has already integrated with VISA, using an EAS for transacting online payments and therefore, parsing online authorizations.
Even though this header is not strictly part of a generic iso message, do you plan adding capabilities to this module for also parsing this value?

Thanks!

events.title: Polymorphism: relationships not populated for subtypes
events.comment:
Thanks for your fast feedback on the changes.
Yes, take your time and challenge us with your domain model 😁 
In more details: 
The problem in detail is _not_ that `Company` has `Persons` in general. But the deeper relationship mapping will only look for something like `Developers_ProgrammingLanguages` in the result, because SDN knows / did not know at this point that the definition for the result in the query creation was named `Person_ProgrammingLanguage`. That's because we collect all fields of the defined type and all its sub-types under the name of the defined type _not_ the concrete property/relationship defining sub-type. This originates from a former bug fix.

This should create a snapshot release in ~30 minutes (from this post timestamp on 😄 ) for you to check out with your example or project.

events.title: Polymorphism: relationships not populated for subtypes
events.comment:
Thanks for the report. A first glance shows that the problem is somewhere between query generator and mapper.
SDN will try its best to gather all fields from the extending classes (in this case `Developer`) but only knows about the `Person` as the field. This leads to the situation that the naming of the returned list for the languages is wrong or the detection algorithm does not pick this up with the right prefix.
I will investigate this in more detail tomorrow. What surprises me is that this is a problem, we solved a long time ago. And your inheritance chain is far from being complex.

events.title: Deleting and creating of new nodes results in merged nodes
events.body: Step 0: Empty database Step 1: Creating a new node of (here of type Catalog) with just simple data (in screenshots with ID 89). Step 2: Building about 5000 nodes, connect them to catalog and save each of them via repo/session.save Step 3: Building a lot of nodes (no saving yet) (at least ~20k) Step 4: Fill the created new Catalog node with data and connect with the builded nodes from steps 2 and 3 and save the catalog node (and implicitly the connected nodes) via repo/transaction/session.save Step 5: Repeat Step 1,2,3 Step 6: Deleting the catalog node from step 1 (ID 89) (via repo/session.query) with connected nodes. It results in a database without the nodes. Fine so far. Step 7: Repeat Step 4 to save the new catalog (in screenshot Catalog with ID 26626) Result: Always (But always only **one**) of the connected nodes shares the Id, label and properties of the **old** catalog (ID 89, which we have deleted in step 6). See Screenshots 7_0 and 7_1 ## Expected Behavior Deleting of nodes should final delete the nodes from database. Reusing of ids via database or ogm should be fine, so saving new nodes should not be merge with previously deleted nodes ## Current Behavior New created nodes will be merged with deleted ones. Which results in an `[AmbiguousBaseClassException: Multiple classes found in type hierarchy that map to: [MY_NODE, MY_OTHER_NODE]]` ## Context This results in an inconsistent and no longer usable database, due to AmbiguousBaseClassException inside ogm which is at least correct. ## Your Environment - Java version: openjdk 17 2021-09-14 - Neo4j version: (4.3.3-community, 4.1.10-community, 4.1.10-arm64 (on our M1)) - OGM Version (The version of this software): 3.2.25 - OGM Transport used (One of Bolt, HTTP or embedded): Bolt - Neo4j Java Driver version (in case of Bolt transport): 3.2.25 - Scala version: 2.6.15 - Playframework version: 2.8.8 Step 0: Step 1: Step 4: Step 5: Step 6: Step 7_0: Step 7_1: Catalog Node: BaseNode:
events.comment:
I feel really sorry, that we have missed this issue over a year.
As your workaround already describes it somehow, I think that the underlying problem is the id handling (re-using) in Neo4j in combination with the caching mechanism of Neo4j-OGM.
If there is still some interest in the problem and a solution, I would need to know how the process in your code looks like. Is it the same session all the way or do you call the repetitions with newly created sessions etc.

events.title: Cached objects from session are different than object in the database
events.comment: No feedback provided in more than 6 months. Closing this now.

events.title: Cached objects from session are different than object in the database
Session-bound cache breaks Read Committed Isolation Level
events.body:
### Setup
- Neo4j OGM 3.2.31
- In Process Neo4j 4.4.4 Enterprise (with BOLT port exposed)
- Spring Boot 2.6.4
- Spring Data Neo4j 5.3.9.RELEASE (connected using [this example](https://github.com/michael-simons/neo4j-from-the-jvm-ecosystem/tree/41e0fded281a71758263d1924a85eede72e00f70/spring-boot26-with-sdn-ogm))

### Issue
Neo4j's isolation level is Read Committed. If I start a transaction, subsequent MATCH queries within the same transaction may show different results if the data in the database changes in the meantime.
OGM behaves differently. As long as there is no write operation from within the same transaction or an active call to session.clear(), it does not reflect changes from the database for entities that have already been loaded before within the same transaction.

Reproduction case:
1. 3 Threads T1, T2, T3 perform the following operations
2. T1 starts a transaction, creates an entity and commits the transaction
3. T2 starts a transaction and reads the entity that was created by T1; T2 keeps its transaction running
4. T3 starts a transaction, modifies the entity in the DB and commits the transaction
5. T2 reads the same entity again

-> In step 5. OGM returns the object from its cache and does not realize the entity was changed in the database. I query all people with last name Miller and OGM suddenly presents me people with last name Doe.

events.title: Session-bound cache breaks Read Committed Isolation Level
events.body:
### Setup
- Neo4j OGM 3.2.31
- In Process Neo4j 4.4.4 Enterprise (with BOLT port exposed)
- Spring Boot 2.6.4
- Spring Data Neo4j 5.3.9.RELEASE (connected using [this example](https://github.com/michael-simons/neo4j-from-the-jvm-ecosystem/tree/41e0fded281a71758263d1924a85eede72e00f70/spring-boot26-with-sdn-ogm))

### Issue
Neo4j's isolation level is Read Committed. If I start a transaction, subsequent MATCH queries within the same transaction may show different results if the data in the database changes in the meantime.
OGM behaves differently. As long as there is no write operation from within the same transaction or an active call to session.clear(), it does not reflect changes from the database for entities that have already been loaded before within the same transaction.

Reproduction case:
1. 3 Threads T1, T2, T3 perform the following operations
2. T1 starts a transaction, creates an entity and commits the transaction
3. T2 starts a transaction and reads the entity that was created by T1; T2 keeps its transaction running
4. T3 starts a transaction, modifies the entity in the DB and commits the transaction
5. T2 reads the same entity again

-> In step 5. OGM returns the object from its cache and does not realize the entity was changed in the database. I query all people with last name Miller and OGM suddenly presents me people with last name Doe.

events.title: @Transient problem
events.comment:
Thanks for reaching out to us.
I thought about your problem / feature request for a while. In the end, it would not work out to bring support for `@Transient` into the fields that are required for the relationship definition, namely `@StartNode` and `@EndNode` because Neo4j-OGM needs to know between which nodes the relationship needs to get created or updated.
Could you maybe explain more the use case and the problem you are trying to solve with this? Maybe we can figure out an alternative approach.

events.comment:
Neo4j-OGM 4 is not designed to be a drop-in replacement for Spring Data Neo4j's Neo4j-OGM dependency.
Referring here to my comment on #914 : https://github.com/neo4j/neo4j-ogm/issues/914#issuecomment-1342779270

Also closing this because there is little we can do.

events.title: Neo4j OGM for Neo4j 5.x
events.body: Hi! Are there any plans to support SDN 5.3.9.RELEASE with OGM for Neo4j 5.x ? If so, when approximately the OGM version will be available on the market for Neo4j 5.x? Thanks!

events.title: Neo4j OGM for Neo4j 5.x
events.body: Hi! Are there any plans to support SDN 5.3.9.RELEASE with OGM for Neo4j 5.x ? If so, when approximately the OGM version will be available on the market for Neo4j 5.x? Thanks!
events.comment:
As you might have noticed already, Neo4j-OGM 4.0 went out last week https://github.com/neo4j/neo4j-ogm/releases/tag/v4.0.0
This release is *not* API compatible with SDN 5.3.
It has a Java 17 base line (as also the Java Driver 5.x requires) and we removed the whole auto index feature.
Because the SDN 5 versions are EOL since February https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-data-commons/wiki/Release-Train-Neumann there is basically no officially supported way to get a release that would adapt Neo4j-OGM 4.0 as the foundational mapping framework.
I will close this issue now, but if you have further thoughts, please feel free to comment.

events.title: Scripts work when users have configured pushd directory
events.body: More details to be provided by @jprinet soon.
events.comment:
## Description
Using [cdpath](https://www.theunixschool.com/2012/04/what-is-cdpath.html) can lead to failure while running the scripts. The behavior of `pushd` can be modified by `cdpath` and the directory can be changed to an unexpected directory.

## Issue
The scripts have to be able to locate the build folder.

## Proposal
When adding `.` as first entry to `CDPATH` environment variable, the behavior seems correct.
We could detect presence of CDPATH environment variable and raise a warning or even better unset it in the script environment if possible.

events.title: Enforce Gradle Enterprise URL is set when using it in the Capture Build Scan URL Maven extension
events.body:
## Context
When running a Maven build with the automated validation scripts, a build scan link is added to filter the build scans related to a given run.

This is done through the [Capture Build Scan URL Maven extension](https://github.com/gradle/gradle-enterprise-build-validation-scripts/blob/6ba97dad760344b0df6f37a5355149a07cb968a1/components/capture-build-scan-url-maven-extension/src/main/java/com/gradle/CaptureBuildScansListener.java#L54).

## Issue
We can not necessarily ensure the ordering in which extensions are applied and that can lead to consuming the Gradle Enterprise server URL before it is actually set by the Gradle Enterprise main extension, which in turn leads to a NullPointerException [there](https://github.com/gradle/gradle-enterprise-build-validation-scripts/blob/6ba97dad760344b0df6f37a5355149a07cb968a1/components/capture-build-scan-url-maven-extension/src/main/java/com/gradle/CaptureBuildScansListener.java#L61).

## Proposal
Encapsulate the access in a `api.buildFinished` block to ensure the value is set.
